CHEM_BOND_E_001.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_001.question_text: Among the following molecules, which one has the highest bond polarity? (Electronegativity: H=2.1, C=2.5, N=3.0, O=3.5, F=4.0)
CHEM_BOND_E_001.question_text_html: Among the following molecules, which one has the highest bond polarity? (Electronegativity: H=2.1, C=2.5, N=3.0, O=3.5, F=4.0)

solution_steps.description: Calculate electronegativity difference for each bond
solution_steps.explanation: Bond polarity increases with electronegativity difference between bonded atoms
Since H-F bond has the maximum electronegativity difference, it has the highest bond polarity among the given options

CHEM_BOND_E_001.jee_pattern: Direct concept application on electronegativity and bond polarity

common_mistakes: Confusing bond polarity with molecular polarity
Not calculating electronegativity differences for all options
metadata.hint: Bond polarity depends on electronegativity difference between atoms
metadata.key_insight: Fluorine being most electronegative creates highest polarity with hydrogen
metadata.elimination_strategy: F is most electronegative, so H-F must be most polar

distractor_analysis.B: H-O has second highest electronegativity difference but still less than H-F
distractor_analysis.C: H-N has moderate electronegativity difference, tempting if F's high value is overlooked
distractor_analysis.D: H-C has lowest electronegativity difference, nearly non-polar

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Easy MCQ with direct concept application

CHEM_BOND_E_002.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_002.question_text: A molecule AB₃ has sp² hybridization at the central atom A with no lone pairs. What is the bond angle (in degrees) between any two A-B bonds?
CHEM_BOND_E_002.question_text_html: A molecule AB₃ has sp² hybridization at the central atom A with no lone pairs. What is the bond angle (in degrees) between any two A-B bonds?

solution_steps.explanation: sp² hybridization with no lone pairs results in trigonal planar geometry where three hybrid orbitals are arranged in a plane

solution_steps.description: Determine bond angle for trigonal planar geometry
solution_steps.explanation: In trigonal planar geometry, the three bonds are equally spaced around the central atom in a plane, giving equal angles of 120°

common_mistakes: Confusing sp² geometry with sp³ tetrahedral (109.5°)
Not accounting for absence of lone pairs
metadata.hint: sp² hybridization always gives trigonal planar geometry when no lone pairs are present
metadata.key_insight: The number of hybrid orbitals and their spatial arrangement determine bond angles

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Easy numerical with direct hybridization recall

CHEM_BOND_E_003.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_003.image_description: Lewis structure of carbon dioxide (CO₂) showing O=C=O with two double bonds. Each oxygen has two lone pairs shown as dots, and carbon has no lone pairs. Linear arrangement.
CHEM_BOND_E_003.image_alt_text: Lewis structure of CO2 molecule showing linear arrangement with double bonds
CHEM_BOND_E_003.diagram_code_python:
from rdkit import Chem
from rdkit.Chem import Draw
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create CO2 molecule
mol = Chem.MolFromSmiles('O=C=O')
img = Draw.MolToImage(mol, size=(300, 200))

CHEM_BOND_E_003.question_text: In the Lewis structure of CO₂ shown in the diagram, how many total valence electrons are present?
CHEM_BOND_E_003.question_text_html: In the Lewis structure of CO₂ shown in the diagram, how many total valence electrons are present?

solution_steps.description: Count valence electrons for each atom
solution_steps.calculation: C: 4 valence electrons (Group 14); O: 6 valence electrons each (Group 16)
solution_steps.explanation: Carbon is in Group 14 with 4 valence electrons, oxygen is in Group 16 with 6 valence electrons

solution_steps.description: Calculate total valence electrons in CO₂
solution_steps.explanation: Add valence electrons from one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms

CHEM_BOND_E_003.jee_pattern: Basic Lewis structure and electron counting

metadata.formula_used: Total valence e⁻ = sum of individual valence electrons
common_mistakes: Counting total electrons instead of only valence electrons
Forgetting to count electrons from both oxygen atoms
metadata.hint: Valence electrons = Group number for main group elements
metadata.key_insight: CO₂ has 16 valence electrons distributed as 4 bonds (8e⁻) and 4 lone pairs (8e⁻)
metadata.elimination_strategy: Carbon has 4, each oxygen has 6, so minimum is 4+6+6=16, eliminates A and B

distractor_analysis.A: Counted only bonding electrons (4 bonds × 2 e⁻ = 8), forgot lone pairs
distractor_analysis.B: Miscounted by including only 1 oxygen or partial lone pairs
distractor_analysis.D: Added extra electrons or counted some core electrons

CHEM_BOND_E_004.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_004.question_text: Which of the following molecules has a bent (angular) shape according to VSEPR theory?
CHEM_BOND_E_004.question_text_html: Which of the following molecules has a bent (angular) shape according to VSEPR theory?

solution_steps.description: Analyze electron pairs around central atom in each molecule
solution_steps.explanation: H₂O: 2 bond pairs + 2 lone pairs on O; CO₂: 2 bond pairs + 0 lone pairs on C; BF₃: 3 bond pairs + 0 lone pairs on B; CH₄: 4 bond pairs + 0 lone pairs on C

solution_steps.description: Apply VSEPR theory to determine shapes
solution_steps.explanation: H₂O has tetrahedral electron geometry but bent molecular shape due to 2 lone pairs; CO₂ is linear; BF₃ is trigonal planar; CH₄ is tetrahedral

concepts_tested: Effect of lone pairs on shape
CHEM_BOND_E_004.jee_pattern: VSEPR theory application to identify molecular shapes

metadata.formula_used: VSEPR: lone pairs cause bent shape from tetrahedral arrangement
common_mistakes: Confusing electron geometry with molecular geometry
Not considering lone pairs in shape determination
metadata.hint: Lone pairs on central atom cause deviation from ideal geometry
metadata.key_insight: Water's two lone pairs compress the H-O-H angle to ~104.5°, making it bent
metadata.elimination_strategy: CO₂ and BF₃ have no lone pairs so can't be bent; CH₄ is 3D tetrahedral

distractor_analysis.B: CO₂ is linear, not bent, due to sp hybridization and no lone pairs
distractor_analysis.C: BF₃ is trigonal planar with no lone pairs on boron
distractor_analysis.D: CH₄ is tetrahedral, a 3D shape, not bent

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Easy VSEPR question with common molecules

CHEM_BOND_E_005.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_005.question_text: Calculate the bond order of O₂ molecule. Given the molecular orbital configuration: σ1s² σ*1s² σ2s² σ*2s² σ2pz² π2px² π2py² π*2px¹ π*2py¹ (showing unpaired electrons in antibonding π orbitals).
CHEM_BOND_E_005.question_text_html: Calculate the bond order of O₂ molecule. Given the molecular orbital configuration: σ1s² σ*1s² σ2s² σ*2s² σ2pz² π2px² π2py² π*2px¹ π*2py¹ (showing unpaired electrons in antibonding π orbitals).

solution_steps.calculation: Bonding: σ1s² + σ2s² + σ2p² + π2p⁴ = 10 electrons; Antibonding: σ*1s² + σ*2s² + π*2p² = 6 electrons
solution_steps.explanation: Bonding molecular orbitals stabilize the molecule while antibonding orbitals destabilize it

Count bonding electrons: σ1s² + σ2s² + σ2pz² + π2px² + π2py² = 10 bonding electrons. Count antibonding electrons: σ*1s² + σ*2s² + π*2px¹ + π*2py¹ = 6 antibonding electrons. Note: The two electrons in π*2p are UNPAIRED (one in π*2px, one in π*2py) according to Hund's rule, making O₂ paramagnetic

CHEM_BOND_E_005.jee_pattern: Direct bond order calculation from MO configuration

common_mistakes: Not dividing by 2 in bond order formula
metadata.hint: Bond order = (bonding electrons - antibonding electrons) / 2
metadata.key_insight: MOT correctly predicts O₂ paramagnetism due to two unpaired electrons in π*2p orbitals

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Easy numerical with direct formula application

CHEM_BOND_E_006.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_006.question_text: Which of the following factors does NOT affect the lattice energy of an ionic compound?
CHEM_BOND_E_006.question_text_html: Which of the following factors does NOT affect the lattice energy of an ionic compound?

solution_steps.description: Recall lattice energy definition and formula
solution_steps.explanation: Lattice energy depends on charges (Q₁, Q₂) and distance between ions (r), which relates to ionic sizes
solution_steps.result: U depends on charge and size

solution_steps.explanation: A) Charge directly affects U; B) Ionic size affects r; C) Crystal structure affects coordination; D) Electronegativity determines whether ionic bond forms but doesn't affect lattice energy magnitude once ions are formed

CHEM_BOND_E_006.jee_pattern: Conceptual question on factors affecting lattice energy

common_mistakes: Thinking electronegativity affects lattice energy after ions form
Confusing bond formation tendency with lattice energy
metadata.hint: Lattice energy is about electrostatic attraction between pre-formed ions
metadata.key_insight: Electronegativity determines IF an ionic bond forms, but lattice energy depends on charge and size of ions
metadata.elimination_strategy: Lattice energy formula has Q and r, eliminating A, B, C

distractor_analysis.A: Charge definitely affects lattice energy (appears in numerator)
distractor_analysis.B: Ionic size affects interionic distance r (smaller ions → higher lattice energy)
distractor_analysis.C: Crystal structure affects coordination number and lattice energy

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Easy concept question with negative phrasing

CHEM_BOND_E_007.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_007.question_text: In the molecule BF₃, how many total orbitals participate in the hybridization of the central boron atom?
CHEM_BOND_E_007.question_text_html: In the molecule BF₃, how many total orbitals participate in the hybridization of the central boron atom?

solution_steps.description: Determine hybridization of boron in BF₃
solution_steps.explanation: BF₃ has 3 bond pairs and 0 lone pairs on boron, requiring sp² hybridization
sp² means 1 s orbital + 2 p orbitals mix to form 3 sp² hybrid orbitals

common_mistakes: Counting hybrid orbitals formed instead of orbitals participating
metadata.hint: The superscript in sp² tells you how many p orbitals are involved
metadata.key_insight: Number after 'sp' indicates p orbitals used; total = 1(s) + number from superscript

CHEM_BOND_E_008.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_008.question_text: In which of the following molecules is hydrogen bonding NOT possible?
CHEM_BOND_E_008.question_text_html: In which of the following molecules is hydrogen bonding NOT possible?

solution_steps.explanation: Hydrogen bonding requires H bonded to highly electronegative atom (F, O, or N) with lone pair
solution_steps.result: Need H-F, H-O, or H-N bond

solution_steps.explanation: A) H₂O has H-O bonds ✓; B) NH₃ has H-N bonds ✓; C) HF has H-F bond ✓; D) CH₄ has H-C bonds where C is not sufficiently electronegative ✗

metadata.formula_used: H-bonding: H bonded to F, O, or N
common_mistakes: Thinking any H-containing molecule can form H-bonds
metadata.hint: Hydrogen bonding requires F, O, or N atoms bonded to hydrogen
metadata.key_insight: Carbon's electronegativity (2.5) is too low to enable hydrogen bonding
metadata.elimination_strategy: Only F, O, N can form H-bonds; C is not in this list

distractor_analysis.A: Water extensively forms H-bonds due to H-O bonds and two lone pairs on O
distractor_analysis.B: Ammonia forms H-bonds due to H-N bonds and one lone pair on N
distractor_analysis.C: HF forms very strong H-bonds, strongest among all molecules

CHEM_BOND_E_009.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_009.question_text: Arrange the C-C bond lengths in increasing order: ethane (C₂H₆), ethene (C₂H₄), ethyne (C₂H₂). If ethane has the longest bond, ethene intermediate, and ethyne shortest, enter 1 for ethyne having shortest bond length.
CHEM_BOND_E_009.question_text_html: Arrange the C-C bond lengths in increasing order: ethane (C₂H₆), ethene (C₂H₄), ethyne (C₂H₂). If ethane has the longest bond, ethene intermediate, and ethyne shortest, enter 1 for ethyne having shortest bond length.

solution_steps.description: Identify bond types in each molecule
solution_steps.explanation: Ethane: C-C single bond; Ethene: C=C double bond; Ethyne: C≡C triple bond
Higher bond order → shorter bond length → stronger bond. Triple bond < double bond < single bond in length
solution_steps.result: Ethyne (120 pm) < Ethene (134 pm) < Ethane (154 pm)

CHEM_BOND_E_009.jee_pattern: Comparison of bond parameters across molecules

common_mistakes: Reversing the order thinking more bonds means longer length
Not understanding inverse relationship between bond order and length
metadata.hint: Triple bonds are shortest, single bonds are longest
metadata.key_insight: Increasing bond order leads to greater electron density between atoms, pulling them closer

CHEM_BOND_E_010.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_E_010.image_description: Resonance structures of benzene (C₆H₆) showing two Kekulé structures with alternating single and double bonds in the hexagonal ring. Both structures connected by double-headed arrow indicating resonance.
CHEM_BOND_E_010.image_alt_text: Two resonance structures of benzene showing alternating double bonds
CHEM_BOND_E_010.diagram_code_python:
from rdkit import Chem
from rdkit.Chem import Draw
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create two benzene structures
mol1 = Chem.MolFromSmiles('C1=CC=CC=C1')
img = Draw.MolToImage(mol1, size=(300, 250))

plt.figure(figsize=(5, 4))
plt.imshow(img)

CHEM_BOND_E_010.question_text: The benzene molecule shown in the diagram exhibits resonance. What is the C-C bond order in benzene considering resonance?
CHEM_BOND_E_010.question_text_html: The benzene molecule shown in the diagram exhibits resonance. What is the C-C bond order in benzene considering resonance?

solution_steps.explanation: Benzene has two equivalent Kekulé structures with alternating single and double C-C bonds. Due to resonance, all C-C bonds are equivalent

solution_steps.calculation: Each position has single bond in one structure, double bond in other. Average = (1 + 2)/2 = 1.5
solution_steps.explanation: Resonance delocalizes electrons, making each C-C bond intermediate between single and double

CHEM_BOND_E_010.jee_pattern: Resonance and average bond order in aromatic systems

metadata.formula_used: Bond order = (sum of bond orders in all structures)/(number of structures)
common_mistakes: Taking bond order as 1 or 2 from individual structure
metadata.hint: In resonance, bond order is average of all contributing structures
metadata.key_insight: Benzene's stability comes from resonance delocalization giving equal 1.5 bond order to all C-C bonds
metadata.elimination_strategy: Pure single (1.0) or double (2.0) would mean no resonance; triple bond impossible

distractor_analysis.A: Would be true if only single bonds present, ignores resonance
distractor_analysis.C: Would be true if only double bonds present, ignores alternating structure
distractor_analysis.D: Triple bonds not possible in benzene ring structure

CHEM_BOND_M_001.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_001.image_description: 3D structure of ammonia (NH₃) showing trigonal pyramidal geometry with nitrogen at apex. Three N-H bonds pointing downward and one lone pair on nitrogen pointing upward. Bond angle labeled as approximately 107°.
CHEM_BOND_M_001.image_alt_text: NH3 molecule showing trigonal pyramidal shape with lone pair on nitrogen
CHEM_BOND_M_001.diagram_code_python:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(6, 5))
ax = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')

# Central N atom
ax.scatter([0], [0], [0], c='blue', s=300, alpha=0.8, label='N')

# Three H atoms in trigonal pyramidal arrangement
angle = np.radians(107)
h_positions = [
    [0.8*np.cos(0), 0.8*np.sin(0), -0.5],
    [0.8*np.cos(2*np.pi/3), 0.8*np.sin(2*np.pi/3), -0.5],
    [0.8*np.cos(4*np.pi/3), 0.8*np.sin(4*np.pi/3), -0.5]
]

for pos in h_positions:
    ax.scatter([pos[0]], [pos[1]], [pos[2]], c='gray', s=200, alpha=0.8)
    ax.plot([0, pos[0]], [0, pos[1]], [0, pos[2]], 'k-', linewidth=2)

# Lone pair
ax.scatter([0], [0], [0.6], c='red', s=150, alpha=0.5, marker='^', label='Lone pair')

ax.set_xlabel('X')
ax.set_ylabel('Y')
ax.set_zlabel('Z')
ax.set_title('NH₃ - Trigonal Pyramidal', fontsize=12)
ax.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig('nh3_structure.png', dpi=150)
plt.close()
CHEM_BOND_M_001.question_text: The structure of NH₃ is shown in the diagram. Why is the H-N-H bond angle (107°) less than the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5°?
CHEM_BOND_M_001.question_text_html: The structure of NH₃ is shown in the diagram. Why is the H-N-H bond angle (107°) less than the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5°?

options.text: The lone pair on nitrogen repels bonding pairs more strongly
options.html: The lone pair on nitrogen repels bonding pairs more strongly

options.text: Hydrogen atoms are too small to maintain 109.5° angle
options.html: Hydrogen atoms are too small to maintain 109.5° angle

options.text: Nitrogen has lower electronegativity than carbon

CHEM_BOND_M_001.correct_answer_text: The lone pair on nitrogen repels bonding pairs more strongly

solution_steps.explanation: NH₃ has 3 N-H bonding pairs and 1 lone pair on nitrogen, giving 4 electron pairs total requiring sp³ hybridization

solution_steps.description: Apply VSEPR electron pair repulsion order
solution_steps.explanation: Repulsion order: lone pair-lone pair > lone pair-bond pair > bond pair-bond pair. The lone pair occupies more space and repels N-H bonds more strongly
Due to stronger lone pair-bond pair repulsion, the three N-H bonds are pushed closer together, reducing H-N-H angle from ideal 109.5° to 107°

CHEM_BOND_M_001.jee_pattern: VSEPR theory application with reasoning for bond angle deviations

common_mistakes: Not recognizing lone pair's role in bond angle compression
metadata.hint: Lone pairs occupy more space and repel bonding pairs more strongly
metadata.key_insight: Lone pair-bond pair repulsion is the key factor causing deviation from ideal tetrahedral angle
metadata.elimination_strategy: NH₃ has sp³ not sp²; hydrogen size and N electronegativity don't affect angle this way

distractor_analysis.B: Atomic size affects bond length not angle; CH₄ with same sized H has 109.5°
distractor_analysis.C: NH₃ has sp³ hybridization, not sp²
distractor_analysis.D: Electronegativity affects polarity, not geometric bond angles

CHEM_BOND_M_002.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_002.question_text: The O₂⁺ ion has the following molecular orbital configuration: (σ1s)² (σ*1s)² (σ2s)² (σ*2s)² (σ2p)² (π2p)⁴ (π*2p)¹. Calculate the bond order of O₂⁺ ion. Express your answer as a decimal.
CHEM_BOND_M_002.question_text_html: The O₂⁺ ion has the following molecular orbital configuration: (σ1s)² (σ*1s)² (σ2s)² (σ*2s)² (σ2p)² (π2p)⁴ (π*2p)¹. Calculate the bond order of O₂⁺ ion. Express your answer as a decimal.

solution_steps.calculation: Bonding MOs: σ1s(2) + σ2s(2) + σ2p(2) + π2p(4) = 10 electrons
solution_steps.explanation: Sum electrons in all bonding molecular orbitals (σ and π without asterisk)

solution_steps.calculation: Antibonding MOs: σ*1s(2) + σ*2s(2) + π*2p(1) = 5 electrons
solution_steps.explanation: Sum electrons in all antibonding molecular orbitals (marked with asterisk)
Bond order is half the difference between bonding and antibonding electrons

CHEM_BOND_M_002.jee_pattern: MOT bond order calculation for molecular ions

metadata.hint: O₂⁺ has one less electron than O₂, removed from antibonding π*2p
metadata.key_insight: O₂⁺ has higher bond order (2.5) than O₂ (2.0) because electron removed from antibonding orbital

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Medium numerical with careful electron counting

CHEM_BOND_M_003.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_003.question_text: Which of the following ionic compounds has the highest lattice energy? (Ionic radii: Li⁺ = 76 pm, Na⁺ = 102 pm, Mg²⁺ = 72 pm, F⁻ = 133 pm, Cl⁻ = 181 pm)
CHEM_BOND_M_003.question_text_html: Which of the following ionic compounds has the highest lattice energy? (Ionic radii: Li⁺ = 76 pm, Na⁺ = 102 pm, Mg²⁺ = 72 pm, F⁻ = 133 pm, Cl⁻ = 181 pm)

solution_steps.explanation: Lattice energy is directly proportional to product of charges and inversely proportional to interionic distance
solution_steps.result: Higher charge, smaller size → higher U

solution_steps.explanation: MgF₂ and MgCl₂ have higher charge products due to Mg²⁺
Smaller interionic distance gives higher lattice energy
solution_steps.result: MgF₂ has smallest r₀ among high-charge compounds

solution_steps.explanation: MgF₂ combines high charge (+2 on Mg²⁺) with smallest size (F⁻ is smallest anion), giving highest lattice energy

CHEM_BOND_M_003.jee_pattern: Lattice energy comparison requiring both charge and size analysis

common_mistakes: Only considering charge without accounting for size
Choosing LiF based on smallest cation alone
metadata.hint: Lattice energy depends on BOTH charge (Mg²⁺ best) AND size (F⁻ smallest anion)
metadata.key_insight: MgF₂ combines doubly charged cation with smallest anion, maximizing lattice energy
metadata.elimination_strategy: Eliminate NaCl (lowest charge, largest size); compare remaining based on size

distractor_analysis.B: MgCl₂ has high charge but Cl⁻ is larger than F⁻, reducing lattice energy
distractor_analysis.C: LiF has very small ions but only +1 charge on Li⁺, lower than Mg²⁺
distractor_analysis.D: NaCl has both lower charge and larger ions, lowest lattice energy

CHEM_BOND_M_004.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_004.question_text: A molecule AB₂ has two identical polar A-B bonds, each with a dipole moment of 1.5 D. If the molecule has a linear geometry, what is the net dipole moment (in Debye) of the molecule?
CHEM_BOND_M_004.question_text_html: A molecule AB₂ has two identical polar A-B bonds, each with a dipole moment of 1.5 D. If the molecule has a linear geometry, what is the net dipole moment (in Debye) of the molecule?

solution_steps.explanation: In linear geometry, the two A-B bonds are arranged at 180° to each other (B-A-B arrangement)

solution_steps.description: Apply vector addition of dipole moments
solution_steps.explanation: The two equal dipole moments point in opposite directions and cancel each other completely
Despite having polar bonds, the linear AB₂ molecule is non-polar due to symmetry (example: CO₂)

CHEM_BOND_M_004.jee_pattern: Dipole moment calculation with vector cancellation

common_mistakes: Adding magnitudes instead of vector addition
Not considering geometry in dipole cancellation
metadata.hint: Linear geometry causes dipole moments to point in opposite directions
metadata.key_insight: Molecular symmetry can make polar bonds result in non-polar molecule

CHEM_BOND_M_005.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_005.image_description: Lewis structure of H₃O⁺ (hydronium ion) showing oxygen with three O-H bonds and one lone pair. Coordinate bond from H₂O + H⁺ indicated with arrow. Positive charge shown on oxygen.
CHEM_BOND_M_005.image_alt_text: Hydronium ion H3O+ structure showing coordinate bond formation

CHEM_BOND_M_005.question_text: In the formation of H₃O⁺ (hydronium ion) shown in the diagram, H₂O accepts a proton (H⁺). How many coordinate (dative) bonds are present in H₃O⁺?
CHEM_BOND_M_005.question_text_html: In the formation of H₃O⁺ (hydronium ion) shown in the diagram, H₂O accepts a proton (H⁺). How many coordinate (dative) bonds are present in H₃O⁺?

solution_steps.explanation: A coordinate bond forms when one atom donates both electrons for the bond. H₂O donates its lone pair to H⁺ (which has no electrons)
H₂O originally has 2 O-H covalent bonds. When H⁺ is added, oxygen's lone pair forms a third O-H bond (coordinate bond)
Only the bond formed with H⁺ is a coordinate bond. Once formed, all three O-H bonds are equivalent, but origin-wise, only one is coordinate

CHEM_BOND_M_005.jee_pattern: Coordinate bond identification in common ions

metadata.formula_used: Coordinate bond: A → B (both electrons from A)
common_mistakes: Counting all three O-H bonds as coordinate bonds
Not understanding difference between coordinate and covalent bonds
metadata.hint: Coordinate bond forms where lone pair is donated to electron-deficient species
metadata.key_insight: Though all three O-H bonds become equivalent after formation, only the one from H⁺ addition is coordinate in origin
metadata.elimination_strategy: Can't be 0 (bond clearly forms) or 3 (H₂O already had 2 normal bonds)

distractor_analysis.A: Incorrect - a coordinate bond definitely forms when H⁺ is accepted
distractor_analysis.C: Would mean two H⁺ ions were added, forming H₄O²⁺ which doesn't exist
distractor_analysis.D: All three can't be coordinate as H₂O already had two regular O-H bonds

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Medium difficulty concept with diagram support

CHEM_BOND_M_006.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_006.question_text: In the molecule CH₂=C=CH₂ (allene), what is the hybridization state of the central carbon atom?
CHEM_BOND_M_006.question_text_html: In the molecule CH₂=C=CH₂ (allene), what is the hybridization state of the central carbon atom?

solution_steps.explanation: Central C forms two C=C double bonds (one to each CH₂ group). Each double bond consists of 1 σ and 1 π bond
solution_steps.result: 2 σ bonds, 2 π bonds at central C

solution_steps.explanation: Hybridization is determined by number of σ bonds + lone pairs. Central C has 2 σ bonds + 0 lone pairs = 2 hybrid orbitals needed
2 hybrid orbitals means sp hybridization (1s + 1p = 2 sp orbitals). The two unhybridized p orbitals form π bonds

CHEM_BOND_M_006.jee_pattern: Hybridization in molecules with cumulated double bonds

metadata.formula_used: # of σ bonds = # of hybrid orbitals
common_mistakes: Thinking central C is sp² because of double bonds
Counting π bonds in hybridization determination
metadata.hint: Count sigma bonds only to determine hybridization
metadata.key_insight: Cumulated double bonds (C=C=C) result in sp hybridization for central carbon with linear arrangement
metadata.elimination_strategy: sp³ and sp³d can be eliminated as central C has only 2 atoms bonded to it

distractor_analysis.B: sp² would give trigonal planar with 3 σ bonds, but central C has only 2
distractor_analysis.C: sp³ requires 4 σ bonds (tetrahedral), central C has only 2
distractor_analysis.D: sp³d is for 5 σ bonds and involves d-orbitals not available for C

CHEM_BOND_M_007.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_007.question_text: The molecular ion O₂²⁻ has the configuration: (σ1s)² (σ*1s)² (σ2s)² (σ*2s)² (σ2p)² (π2p)⁴ (π*2p)⁴. How many unpaired electrons are present in O₂²⁻?
CHEM_BOND_M_007.question_text_html: The molecular ion O₂²⁻ has the configuration: (σ1s)² (σ*1s)² (σ2s)² (σ*2s)² (σ2p)² (π2p)⁴ (π*2p)⁴. How many unpaired electrons are present in O₂²⁻?

solution_steps.explanation: All molecular orbitals have superscript indicating number of electrons. Check each orbital for pairing

solution_steps.description: Apply Pauli exclusion and Hund's rule
solution_steps.explanation: Each MO can hold 2 electrons with opposite spins. (π*2p)⁴ means all 4 π* electrons are paired (2 in each of two π* orbitals)

solution_steps.description: Count unpaired electrons and determine magnetic property
solution_steps.explanation: Since all electrons are paired, O₂²⁻ is diamagnetic (repelled by magnetic field)

CHEM_BOND_M_007.jee_pattern: Magnetic property determination from MO configuration

metadata.formula_used: Unpaired electrons → paramagnetic; All paired → diamagnetic
common_mistakes: Not recognizing that even superscripts mean all electrons paired
metadata.hint: If total electrons in any orbital set is even and fills completely, all are paired
metadata.key_insight: O₂²⁻ (peroxide ion) is diamagnetic unlike O₂ which is paramagnetic

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Medium numerical requiring careful electron counting

CHEM_BOND_M_008.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_008.question_text: Which of the following molecules has a T-shaped geometry?
CHEM_BOND_M_008.question_text_html: Which of the following molecules has a T-shaped geometry?

solution_steps.description: Determine electron pairs for each molecule
solution_steps.explanation: ClF₃: 3 bp + 2 lp = 5 pairs; BF₃: 3 bp + 0 lp = 3 pairs; NH₃: 3 bp + 1 lp = 4 pairs; PCl₃: 3 bp + 1 lp = 4 pairs
BF₃: trigonal planar; NH₃ & PCl₃: trigonal pyramidal; ClF₃: 5 pairs in trigonal bipyramidal arrangement
solution_steps.result: ClF₃ has trigonal bipyramidal electron geometry

solution_steps.description: Determine molecular shape from lone pair placement
solution_steps.explanation: In ClF₃, 2 lone pairs occupy equatorial positions (less repulsion). 3 F atoms: 2 axial + 1 equatorial, forming T-shape

CHEM_BOND_M_008.jee_pattern: Identification of less common molecular geometries

common_mistakes: Not recognizing that 5 total electron pairs is key for T-shape
metadata.hint: T-shaped requires 5 electron pairs with 2 lone pairs in equatorial positions
metadata.key_insight: Lone pairs preferentially occupy equatorial positions in trigonal bipyramidal arrangement to minimize repulsion
metadata.elimination_strategy: BF₃ is planar; NH₃ and PCl₃ are pyramidal with 4 pairs total

distractor_analysis.B: BF₃ is trigonal planar with no lone pairs on B
distractor_analysis.C: NH₃ is trigonal pyramidal with 1 lone pair
distractor_analysis.D: PCl₃ is also trigonal pyramidal with 1 lone pair

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Medium difficulty with less common geometry

CHEM_BOND_M_009.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_009.question_text: In the carbonate ion (CO₃²⁻), the formal charge on each oxygen atom in the most stable resonance structure is −2/3. What is the formal charge on the carbon atom? Express as a decimal (round to 2 decimal places if needed).
CHEM_BOND_M_009.question_text_html: In the carbonate ion (CO₃²⁻), the formal charge on each oxygen atom in the most stable resonance structure is −2/3. What is the formal charge on the carbon atom? Express as a decimal (round to 2 decimal places if needed).

solution_steps.formula: Sum of formal charges = Overall charge
solution_steps.explanation: The total formal charges on all atoms must equal the overall charge of the ion, which is −2

solution_steps.description: Calculate total formal charge on oxygen atoms
solution_steps.explanation: Three oxygen atoms each with formal charge −2/3 contribute total −2
Since oxygens account for all −2 charge, carbon must have zero formal charge

CHEM_BOND_M_009.jee_pattern: Formal charge calculation in resonance-stabilized ions

common_mistakes: Calculating from scratch instead of using given oxygen charges
metadata.hint: Sum of all formal charges must equal the ion's overall charge
metadata.key_insight: In resonance hybrids, carbon often has zero formal charge when bonded to electronegative atoms

CHEM_BOND_M_010.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_010.question_text: Which of the following factors would increase the lattice energy of an ionic compound?
CHEM_BOND_M_010.question_text_html: Which of the following factors would increase the lattice energy of an ionic compound?

options.text: Increasing the size of the cation
Decreasing the charge on the anion
Increasing the charge on the cation
Increasing the size of the anion

CHEM_BOND_M_010.correct_answer_text: Increasing the charge on the cation

solution_steps.explanation: Lattice energy is directly proportional to product of ionic charges and inversely proportional to interionic distance
solution_steps.result: U increases with charge, decreases with size

solution_steps.explanation: A & D: Larger ions → larger r₀ → lower U; B: Lower charge → lower Q₋ → lower U; C: Higher charge → higher Q₊ → higher U
MgO (Mg²⁺) has much higher lattice energy than NaCl (Na⁺) partly due to higher cation charge
solution_steps.result: Higher cation charge → higher lattice energy

CHEM_BOND_M_010.jee_pattern: Conceptual understanding of lattice energy factors

common_mistakes: Not recognizing charge appears in numerator
metadata.hint: Lattice energy increases with ionic charge and decreases with ionic size
metadata.key_insight: Higher ionic charges lead to stronger electrostatic attraction and higher lattice energy
metadata.elimination_strategy: Size increases (A, D) decrease U; charge decrease (B) decreases U; only C increases both charge and U

distractor_analysis.A: Larger cation increases r₀, which decreases lattice energy
distractor_analysis.B: Lower anion charge reduces Q₋, decreasing lattice energy
distractor_analysis.D: Larger anion increases r₀, which decreases lattice energy

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Medium conceptual question on lattice energy

CHEM_BOND_M_011.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_011.question_text: Arrange the following compounds in increasing order of boiling points: H₂O, H₂S, H₂Se, H₂Te
CHEM_BOND_M_011.question_text_html: Arrange the following compounds in increasing order of boiling points: H₂O, H₂S, H₂Se, H₂Te

solution_steps.explanation: H₂O exhibits strong hydrogen bonding (O is highly electronegative). H₂S, H₂Se, H₂Te have only van der Waals forces (S, Se, Te less electronegative)
solution_steps.result: H₂O has H-bonding; others have only van der Waals

solution_steps.explanation: For H₂S, H₂Se, H₂Te: boiling point increases with molecular size/mass due to stronger London dispersion forces (S < Se < Te)
Despite being smallest, H₂O has highest b.p. (100°C) due to extensive H-bonding network, much higher than H₂Te (−2°C)

CHEM_BOND_M_011.jee_pattern: Boiling point trends with anomalous behavior due to H-bonding

common_mistakes: Following normal trend (size) without considering H-bonding anomaly
Not recognizing only O enables H-bonding in group 16
metadata.hint: Water's hydrogen bonding makes it anomalous in the group
metadata.key_insight: H₂O breaks the normal trend due to strong hydrogen bonding despite being smallest
metadata.elimination_strategy: A & D don't have H₂O highest; C has wrong order for H₂S/H₂Se/H₂Te

distractor_analysis.A: Would be correct if following size trend only, ignores H-bonding in water
distractor_analysis.C: Incorrectly places H₂O between H₂S and heavier analogs
distractor_analysis.D: Reverses the trend for non-H-bonded molecules

CHEM_BOND_M_012.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_012.question_text: In the molecule SF₄, the central sulfur atom has sp³d hybridization with one lone pair. What is the F-S-F bond angle (in degrees) between two equatorial fluorine atoms?
CHEM_BOND_M_012.question_text_html: In the molecule SF₄, the central sulfur atom has sp³d hybridization with one lone pair. What is the F-S-F bond angle (in degrees) between two equatorial fluorine atoms?

solution_steps.explanation: sp³d hybridization with 4 bp + 1 lp = 5 electron pairs gives trigonal bipyramidal electron geometry

solution_steps.description: Position lone pair to minimize repulsion
solution_steps.explanation: Lone pair occupies equatorial position (less repulsion). This leaves 2 equatorial F and 2 axial F, creating see-saw molecular geometry
In trigonal bipyramidal, equatorial positions are 120° apart. Even with lone pair, the two equatorial F atoms maintain approximately 120° angle

CHEM_BOND_M_012.jee_pattern: Bond angle determination in expanded octet molecules

common_mistakes: Not recognizing lone pair position effect
metadata.hint: Equatorial positions in trigonal bipyramidal are 120° apart
metadata.key_insight: Lone pairs preferentially occupy equatorial positions in sp³d geometry

CHEM_BOND_M_013.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_013.image_description: Structure of nitrate ion (NO₃⁻) showing nitrogen at center bonded to three oxygen atoms. One N-O double bond and two N-O single bonds shown, with negative charge distributed. Resonance arrows indicating three equivalent structures.
CHEM_BOND_M_013.image_alt_text: Nitrate ion showing resonance structures with equivalent N-O bonds
CHEM_BOND_M_013.diagram_code_python:
from rdkit import Chem
from rdkit.Chem import Draw
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create nitrate ion
mol = Chem.MolFromSmiles('[O-][N+](=O)[O-]')
img = Draw.MolToImage(mol, size=(300, 250))

plt.figure(figsize=(5, 4))
plt.imshow(img)
plt.axis('off')
plt.title('NO₃⁻ (Nitrate Ion)', fontsize=12)
plt.text(0.5, 0.05, 'All N-O bonds are equivalent due to resonance', 
         transform=plt.gca().transAxes, ha='center', fontsize=9)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig('nitrate.png', dpi=150, bbox_inches='tight')
plt.close()
CHEM_BOND_M_013.question_text: The nitrate ion (NO₃⁻) shown exhibits resonance. What is the average N-O bond order in NO₃⁻?
CHEM_BOND_M_013.question_text_html: The nitrate ion (NO₃⁻) shown exhibits resonance. What is the average N-O bond order in NO₃⁻?

solution_steps.explanation: NO₃⁻ has 3 resonance structures. In each structure, there is 1 N=O double bond and 2 N-O single bonds

solution_steps.calculation: Total bonds across 3 structures: 1(2) + 2(1) = 4 per structure × 3 structures = 4
solution_steps.explanation: Each structure contributes: one double bond (order 2) + two single bonds (order 1 each) = 4 total

solution_steps.description: Calculate average bond order per N-O bond
solution_steps.formula: Average bond order = Total bonds / Number of positions
solution_steps.explanation: 4 total bonds distributed equally among 3 N-O positions gives 1.33 bond order for each

CHEM_BOND_M_013.jee_pattern: Resonance and average bond order in polyatomic ions

metadata.formula_used: Average bond order = (sum of bond orders) / (number of bonds)
common_mistakes: Taking bond order as 1 or 2 from single structure
Not averaging across all resonance structures
metadata.hint: Each resonance structure has 1 double bond and 2 single bonds
metadata.key_insight: Resonance delocalizes the double bond character equally across all three N-O bonds
metadata.elimination_strategy: Pure single (1.0) or double (2.0) would mean no resonance; 1.5 is wrong arithmetic

distractor_analysis.A: Would be true if only single bonds, ignores double bond in resonance
distractor_analysis.C: Incorrect calculation, confuses with benzene's 1.5
distractor_analysis.D: Would mean all double bonds, not possible with 3 oxygens

irt_parameters.calibration_notes: Medium difficulty with diagram and calculation

CHEM_BOND_M_014.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_014.question_text: Based on molecular orbital theory, which species has the stronger bond: N₂ (bond order 3.0) or N₂⁺ (bond order 2.5)? If N₂ has stronger bond, enter 1. If N₂⁺ has stronger bond, enter 2.
CHEM_BOND_M_014.question_text_html: Based on molecular orbital theory, which species has the stronger bond: N₂ (bond order 3.0) or N₂⁺ (bond order 2.5)? If N₂ has stronger bond, enter 1. If N₂⁺ has stronger bond, enter 2.

solution_steps.explanation: Bond strength increases with bond order. Higher bond order means more electrons in bonding MOs relative to antibonding MOs

solution_steps.calculation: N₂: bond order = 3.0; N₂⁺: bond order = 2.5
solution_steps.explanation: N₂ has higher bond order (3.0 > 2.5), therefore stronger bond
Removing electron from N₂ to form N₂⁺ removes it from bonding σ2p orbital, decreasing bond order and strength. N₂ has one of the strongest bonds known (945 kJ/mol)

CHEM_BOND_M_014.jee_pattern: Relative bond strength comparison using MOT

common_mistakes: Thinking ion is stronger due to charge
Not relating bond order to bond strength
metadata.hint: Higher bond order always means stronger, shorter bond
metadata.key_insight: N₂ has exceptionally high bond order (3) making it very stable and unreactive

CHEM_BOND_M_015.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_015.question_text: In which of the following molecules is the magnitude of partial positive charge (δ+) on the central atom the highest? (Electronegativity: H=2.1, C=2.5, O=3.5, F=4.0, Cl=3.0)
CHEM_BOND_M_015.question_text_html: In which of the following molecules is the magnitude of partial positive charge (δ+) on the central atom the highest? (Electronegativity: H=2.1, C=2.5, O=3.5, F=4.0, Cl=3.0)

solution_steps.explanation: Partial positive charge on central atom increases with: (1) higher electronegativity difference, (2) more highly electronegative atoms attached
solution_steps.result: Need high Δχ and multiple electronegative atoms

solution_steps.explanation: F has largest electronegativity difference with C
solution_steps.result: CF₄ has largest Δχ per bond

solution_steps.explanation: CF₄ has 4 C-F bonds, each with Δχ = 1.5, giving maximum electron withdrawal from carbon. CO₂ has 2 C=O bonds with Δχ = 1.0 each
solution_steps.result: CF₄ has highest δ+ on C

CHEM_BOND_M_015.jee_pattern: Electronegativity application to partial charge determination

common_mistakes: Not considering number of bonds (4 in CF₄ vs 2 in CO₂)
Choosing CH₄ where H is less electronegative than C
metadata.hint: F is most electronegative, and CF₄ has 4 C-F bonds
metadata.key_insight: CF₄ combines highest per-bond electronegativity difference with maximum number of bonds
metadata.elimination_strategy: A has negative δ on C; C has smaller Δχ than B or D; B has more bonds than D

distractor_analysis.A: H is less electronegative than C, so C has partial negative charge
distractor_analysis.C: Cl is electronegative but less than F, giving smaller δ+
distractor_analysis.D: O is electronegative but only 2 bonds vs 4 in CF₄

CHEM_BOND_M_016.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_016.question_text: According to Fajans' rules, which of the following ionic compounds has the maximum covalent character?
CHEM_BOND_M_016.question_text_html: According to Fajans' rules, which of the following ionic compounds has the maximum covalent character?

solution_steps.description: Recall Fajans' rules for covalent character
solution_steps.explanation: Covalent character increases with: (1) small, highly charged cation with high polarizing power; (2) large, highly charged anion that is easily polarizable; (3) pseudo-noble gas configuration of cation
solution_steps.result: Small cation, large anion, d¹⁰ configuration favor covalency

solution_steps.explanation: All have Cl⁻ anion. Cations: Na⁺ (1.02 Å, noble gas config), Ag⁺ (1.15 Å, d¹⁰ config), K⁺ (1.38 Å, noble gas), Li⁺ (0.76 Å, noble gas)
Ag⁺ has d¹⁰ configuration (18 electron outer shell) making it highly polarizing despite moderate size. d-electrons screen nuclear charge poorly, enhancing polarizing ability

CHEM_BOND_M_016.jee_pattern: Application of Fajans' rules to predict bonding character

metadata.formula_used: Fajans' rules: covalent character ∝ polarizing power of cation
common_mistakes: Choosing LiCl thinking smallest cation always wins
Not recognizing special nature of Ag⁺ (d¹⁰ configuration)
metadata.hint: Ag⁺ has pseudo-noble gas configuration (d¹⁰) giving high polarizing power
metadata.key_insight: Transition metal cations with d¹⁰ configuration have higher polarizing power than alkali metals
metadata.elimination_strategy: Ag⁺ has d¹⁰ configuration unlike Na⁺, K⁺, Li⁺ which are simple noble gas

distractor_analysis.A: Na⁺ has noble gas configuration, moderate polarizing power
distractor_analysis.C: K⁺ is large with low polarizing power, most ionic of the options
distractor_analysis.D: Li⁺ is smallest but noble gas config, less polarizing than Ag⁺'s d¹⁰

CHEM_BOND_M_017.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_017.question_text: How many total π (pi) bonds are present in the molecule HC≡C-CH=CH₂?
CHEM_BOND_M_017.question_text_html: How many total π (pi) bonds are present in the molecule HC≡C-CH=CH₂?

solution_steps.description: Identify multiple bonds in the molecule
solution_steps.explanation: HC≡C-CH=CH₂ contains: one C≡C triple bond and one C=C double bond

solution_steps.description: Count π bonds in each multiple bond
solution_steps.explanation: Triple bond (C≡C) = 1 σ + 2 π; Double bond (C=C) = 1 σ + 1 π
Add π bonds from both multiple bonds

CHEM_BOND_M_017.jee_pattern: Counting sigma and pi bonds in organic molecules

common_mistakes: Counting σ bonds instead of π bonds
Missing one of the multiple bonds in the structure
metadata.hint: Triple bond has 2 π bonds, double bond has 1 π bond
metadata.key_insight: Every additional bond beyond the first in a multiple bond is a π bond

CHEM_BOND_M_018.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_018.question_text: For the formation of NaCl, the enthalpy of formation is −411 kJ/mol. Given: enthalpy of sublimation of Na = +108 kJ/mol, ionization energy of Na = +496 kJ/mol, bond dissociation energy of Cl₂ = +244 kJ/mol, electron affinity of Cl = −349 kJ/mol. Calculate the lattice energy of NaCl in kJ/mol (magnitude only, positive value).
CHEM_BOND_M_018.question_text_html: For the formation of NaCl, the enthalpy of formation is −411 kJ/mol. Given: enthalpy of sublimation of Na = +108 kJ/mol, ionization energy of Na = +496 kJ/mol, bond dissociation energy of Cl₂ = +244 kJ/mol, electron affinity of Cl = −349 kJ/mol. Calculate the lattice energy of NaCl in kJ/mol (magnitude only, positive value).

solution_steps.formula: ΔH_f = ΔH_sub + IE + ½BDE + EA − U
solution_steps.explanation: Enthalpy of formation equals sum of all steps: sublimation, ionization, atomization (½ for Cl₂), electron affinity, minus lattice energy
Insert all given thermodynamic values. Note: BDE is for Cl₂, so divide by 2 for one Cl atom
Rearrange to find U. Lattice energy is released (negative in formation), but expressed as positive magnitude

CHEM_BOND_M_018.jee_pattern: Born-Haber cycle calculation for lattice energy

metadata.formula_used: ΔH_f = ΔH_sub + IE + ½BDE + EA − U
common_mistakes: Not dividing Cl₂ bond energy by 2
Forgetting lattice energy is subtracted in formation
metadata.hint: Use Born-Haber cycle: ΔH_formation includes all steps leading to crystal formation
metadata.key_insight: Lattice energy is the energy released when gaseous ions form solid crystal

CHEM_BOND_M_019.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_019.question_text: Which of the following statements about formal charges is CORRECT?
CHEM_BOND_M_019.question_text_html: Which of the following statements about formal charges is CORRECT?

options.text: The most stable structure always has zero formal charges on all atoms
options.html: The most stable structure always has zero formal charges on all atoms

options.text: Structures with negative formal charges on more electronegative atoms are more stable
options.html: Structures with negative formal charges on more electronegative atoms are more stable

options.text: The sum of formal charges in a molecule must always be zero
options.html: The sum of formal charges in a molecule must always be zero

options.text: Formal charge represents the actual charge on an atom
options.html: Formal charge represents the actual charge on an atom

CHEM_BOND_M_019.correct_answer_text: Structures with negative formal charges on more electronegative atoms are more stable

solution_steps.explanation: Many stable molecules have non-zero formal charges (e.g., CO, HCN). Zero formal charge is preferred but not always possible or most stable
Placing negative formal charge on more electronegative atoms matches their electron-attracting nature, making structure more stable (e.g., in resonance structures of CO₂, negative on O is favored)
C: Sum equals overall charge of species (0 for neutral, ±n for ions). D: Formal charge is bookkeeping tool, not actual charge distribution

CHEM_BOND_M_019.jee_pattern: Conceptual understanding of formal charge rules

metadata.formula_used: FC = V − N − ½B; Stability rules for formal charges
common_mistakes: Thinking formal charge equals actual charge
Believing all atoms must have zero formal charge
metadata.hint: Most stable structures place negative charge on electronegative atoms
metadata.key_insight: Formal charge helps predict most stable resonance structure: negative on electronegative, positive on electropositive
metadata.elimination_strategy: A is too absolute; C false for ions; D confuses formal with actual charge

distractor_analysis.A: Many stable molecules have formal charges (CO: C has −1, O has +1)
distractor_analysis.C: True only for neutral molecules; ions have non-zero sum
distractor_analysis.D: Formal charge is a bookkeeping convention, not actual electron distribution

CHEM_BOND_M_020.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_M_020.question_text: In a bent AB₂ molecule with a bond angle of 120°, each A-B bond has a dipole moment of 2.0 D. Calculate the resultant dipole moment of the molecule in Debye. (Use: cos 60° = 0.5, √3 ≈ 1.73)
CHEM_BOND_M_020.question_text_html: In a bent AB₂ molecule with a bond angle of 120°, each A-B bond has a dipole moment of 2.0 D. Calculate the resultant dipole moment of the molecule in Debye. (Use: cos 60° = 0.5, √3 ≈ 1.73)

solution_steps.explanation: Two bond dipoles at angle θ = 120° combine vectorially. Use cosine rule for vector addition
Bond angle is 120°, so angle between dipole vectors is also 120°
Substitute μ₁ = μ₂ = 2.0 D and cos(120°) = −0.5 into formula

metadata.hint: Use cosine rule for vector addition; cos(120°) = −0.5
metadata.key_insight: At 120° angle, the negative cosine term reduces the resultant

CHEM_BOND_MH_010.question_text: Which explains why all S-F bonds in SF₆ are equivalent despite sp³d² hybridization?

options.text: Octahedral geometry makes all positions equivalent by symmetry
options.html: Octahedral geometry makes all positions equivalent by symmetry

CHEM_BOND_MH_010.correct_answer_text: Octahedral geometry makes all positions equivalent by symmetry

solution_steps.explanation: SF₆ uses sp³d² hybridization (6 orbitals: 1s + 3p + 2d)
6 electron pairs arrange in octahedral geometry (AX₆)
In octahedral geometry, all 6 positions are geometrically equivalent - each bond at 90° from 4 neighbors, 180° from 1
Despite d-orbital involvement, the high symmetry of octahedral geometry makes all S-F bonds equivalent in length and strength

CHEM_BOND_MH_011.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_MH_011.question_text: The bond angle in H₂S is 92° while in H₂O it is 104.5°, despite both having bent geometry. What is the primary reason for this difference?
CHEM_BOND_MH_011.question_text_html: The bond angle in H₂S is 92° while in H₂O it is 104.5°, despite both having bent geometry. What is the primary reason for this difference?

options.text: Lower electronegativity of S results in less s-character in bonds
options.html: Lower electronegativity of S results in less s-character in bonds

options.text: Larger size of S atom increases repulsion
options.html: Larger size of S atom increases repulsion

options.text: H₂S has more lone pair repulsion
S uses pure p-orbitals while O uses hybridized orbitals
options.html: S uses pure p-orbitals while O uses hybridized orbitals

CHEM_BOND_MH_011.correct_answer_text: Lower electronegativity of S results in less s-character in bonds

solution_steps.explanation: Both H₂O and H₂S have 2 bond pairs + 2 lone pairs (bent geometry)
Lower electronegativity elements use more p-character (less s-character) in bonding. S less electronegative than O
Pure p-orbitals are perpendicular (90°). More p-character → smaller bond angle. H₂S closer to 90° than H₂O
Electronegativity: O (3.5) >> S (2.5). Lower electronegativity → less hybridization → more p-character → angle approaches 90°

CHEM_BOND_MH_013.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_MH_013.question_text: Arrange the following in order of increasing boiling point: H₂O, H₂S, H₂Se, H₂Te. Consider both hydrogen bonding and molecular weight effects.
CHEM_BOND_MH_013.question_text_html: Arrange the following in order of increasing boiling point: H₂O, H₂S, H₂Se, H₂Te.

solution_steps.explanation: Boiling point depends on intermolecular forces: H-bonding >> van der Waals
Only H₂O has strong H-bonding (O highly electronegative). S, Se, Te not electronegative enough for significant H-bonding
For H₂S, H₂Se, H₂Te: boiling point increases with molecular weight (stronger dispersion forces). Order: H₂S < H₂Se < H₂Te
solution_steps.result: Normal trend for S, Se, Te

solution_steps.explanation: Despite lowest molecular weight, H₂O has highest boiling point (100°C) due to extensive H-bonding network. H₂Te (−2°C), H₂Se (−41°C), H₂S (−60°C)
H-bonding in H₂O creates anomaly. Final order: H₂S (−60°C) < H₂Se (−41°C) < H₂Te (−2°C) < H₂O (100°C)

CHEM_BOND_H_001.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_H_001.question_text: Using molecular orbital theory, explain why NO⁺ is diamagnetic while NO is paramagnetic. Both are isoelectronic with N₂ or close to it.
CHEM_BOND_H_001.question_text_html: Using MOT, explain why NO⁺ is diamagnetic while NO is paramagnetic.

options.text: NO has 15 electrons with 1 unpaired; NO⁺ has 14 electrons all paired
options.html: NO has 15 electrons with 1 unpaired; NO⁺ has 14 electrons all paired

options.text: NO⁺ has 1 unpaired electron in π*2p; NO has all paired
options.html: NO⁺ has 1 unpaired electron in π*2p; NO has all paired

options.text: Both have unpaired electrons but NO⁺ pairs them
options.html: Both have unpaired electrons but NO⁺ pairs them

CHEM_BOND_H_001.correct_answer_text: NO has 15 electrons with 1 unpaired; NO⁺ has 14 electrons all paired

solution_steps.explanation: NO: 15 valence electrons (7+8). NO⁺: 14 valence electrons (lost 1)

solution_steps.calculation: NO (15e⁻): σ2s² σ*2s² σ2pz² π2px² π2py² π*2px¹
solution_steps.explanation: Odd number of electrons → must have unpaired electron in π*2p

solution_steps.calculation: NO⁺ (14e⁻): σ2s² σ*2s² σ2pz² π2px² π2py²
solution_steps.explanation: Even number, all orbitals filled with pairs. Isoelectronic with N₂
NO paramagnetic (1 unpaired). NO⁺ diamagnetic (0 unpaired). Removal of electron from π*2p antibonding also increases bond order from 2.5 to 3.0
MOT correctly predicts: NO (15e⁻) paramagnetic, NO⁺ (14e⁻) diamagnetic. This demonstrates power of MOT for electron configuration

metadata.hint: Helpful hint
metadata.key_insight: Key insight

distractor_analysis.B: Reversed - NO⁺ is the one that's paired
distractor_analysis.C: NO⁺ doesn't pair them, it removes the unpaired electron
distractor_analysis.D: MOT doesn't use hybridization concept

CHEM_BOND_H_003.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_H_003.question_text: Which theory correctly predicts that O₂ is paramagnetic, and why does the other theory fail?
CHEM_BOND_H_003.question_text_html: Which theory correctly predicts that O₂ is paramagnetic, and why does the other theory fail?

options.text: MOT predicts paramagnetism due to unpaired electrons in π*2p; VBT shows all electrons paired in double bond
options.html: MOT predicts paramagnetism due to unpaired electrons in π*2p; VBT shows all electrons paired in double bond

options.text: VBT predicts paramagnetism; MOT fails to account for electron spin
options.html: VBT predicts paramagnetism; MOT fails to account for electron spin

options.text: Both theories predict paramagnetism equally well
Neither theory can explain O₂ magnetism

CHEM_BOND_H_003.correct_answer_text: MOT predicts paramagnetism due to unpaired electrons in π*2p; VBT shows all electrons paired

solution_steps.explanation: O₂ is experimentally paramagnetic (attracted to magnetic field), indicating unpaired electrons

solution_steps.calculation: VBT: O=O double bond with all 12 valence electrons paired
solution_steps.explanation: VBT shows Lewis structure O=O with complete octets, all electrons paired → predicts diamagnetic (WRONG)
MOT fills antibonding π*2p with 2 unpaired electrons (Hund's rule) → predicts paramagnetic (CORRECT)

VBT assumes localized electron pairs in bonds. Cannot explain why antibonding orbitals would have unpaired electrons. VBT fundamentally limited for molecules with unpaired electrons in antibonding orbitals
MOT's key advantage: allows electrons in antibonding orbitals and applies Hund's rule correctly. This explains O₂ paramagnetism, bond order (2), and why O₂ readily accepts electrons (strong oxidizer)

metadata.hint: Helpful hint
metadata.key_insight: Key insight

distractor_analysis.B: Completely backwards - VBT is the one that fails
distractor_analysis.C: False - VBT explicitly fails for O₂
distractor_analysis.D: MOT successfully explains it

CHEM_BOND_H_005.question_text: The Born-Landé equation for lattice energy is U = (N_A M z⁺z⁻ e²)/(4πε₀r₀)(1 - 1/n). Which factor has the MOST significant impact on increasing the lattice energy of an ionic compound?
CHEM_BOND_H_005.question_text_html: The Born-Landé equation for lattice energy is U = (N_A M z⁺z⁻ e²)/(4πε₀r₀)(1 - 1/n). Which factor has the MOST significant impact on increasing the lattice energy?

options.text: Increasing the product of ionic charges (z⁺ × z⁻)
options.html: Increasing the product of ionic charges (z⁺ × z⁻)

CHEM_BOND_H_005.correct_answer_text: Increasing the product of ionic charges

solution_steps.explanation: Lattice energy is directly proportional to charge product and inversely proportional to distance
Ionic charge appears as product in numerator - multiplicative effect
Distance in denominator - inverse linear effect
M varies only slightly (1.6-1.8 for common structures). Born exponent n (5-12) appears in minor correction term (1-1/n)
solution_steps.result: M and n have modest effects

solution_steps.explanation: Example: MgO vs NaCl. Charge product increases 4× (from 1 to 4), dominates over size difference. MgO lattice energy ≈ 3850 kJ/mol vs NaCl ≈ 786 kJ/mol
solution_steps.result: Answer A: Charge product most significant

metadata.hint: Helpful hint
metadata.key_insight: Key insight

distractor_analysis.B: Distance important but linear effect, not quadratic like charge
distractor_analysis.C: Madelung constant varies only 1.6-1.8, minor compared to charge
distractor_analysis.D: Born exponent in correction term (1-1/n), smallest effect

Each C-C bond has 1 σ component (total 6)
Each C-H bond is pure σ bond

CHEM_BOND_MH_016.subject: Chemistry
CHEM_BOND_MH_016.question_text: Which of the following has maximum lattice energy? (Ionic radii in pm: Li⁺=76, Na⁺=102, Be²⁺=31, Mg²⁺=72, F⁻=133, O²⁻=140)
CHEM_BOND_MH_016.question_text_html: Which of the following has maximum lattice energy? (Ionic radii: Li⁺=76, Na⁺=102, Be²⁺=31, Mg²⁺=72, F⁻=133, O²⁻=140 pm)

solution_steps.description: Strategic Setup - Recall lattice energy factors
solution_steps.explanation: Lattice energy increases with charge product and decreases with size
solution_steps.result: Higher charge + smaller size → higher U

solution_steps.explanation: Doubly charged ions give 4× higher charge product
BeO has smallest interionic distance
BeO combines highest charge product (4) with smallest size (171 pm)
Actual lattice energies: BeO ≈ 4443, MgO ≈ 3850, LiF ≈ 1037, NaF ≈ 923 kJ/mol confirms prediction

CHEM_BOND_MH_016.jee_pattern: Lattice energy comparison with multiple factors

common_mistakes: Only considering charge or only size
metadata.hint: Both charge AND size matter; Be²⁺ is extremely small
metadata.key_insight: BeO has exceptionally high lattice energy due to very small Be²⁺ and doubly charged ions

distractor_analysis.B: MgO has high charge but Mg²⁺ larger than Be²⁺
distractor_analysis.C: LiF has small ions but only +1 charge
distractor_analysis.D: NaF has both lower charge and larger size
